p: Viral capsid antigen can be detected in the blood of those infected with HEV even before the patient becomes clinically symptomatic and persists for approximately 4Â weeks. Testing for capsid antigen is technically less demanding and can be performed even without molecular detection laboratories. It can be detected using an indirect sandwich enzyme immunoassay, with an estimated sensitivity of 91% and specificity of 100% [ 38]. Studies have demonstrated waning levels of capsid antigen in blood of patients with HEV infection correlated with rising levels of anti-HEV antibodies [ 39]. Thus, it has a lower sensitivity for the detection of acute infection than HEV RNA and IgM anti-HEV [ 39]. However, ease of performing the diagnosis combined with a lower cost than RNA detection makes it an attractive option for blood screening and in early diagnosis of HEV infection.
